questions.question: She was …………………………… frightened ………………………… she could not even move.
questions.description: So..that.... shows cause and effect.

questions.question: ………………………….. she is rich and influential, she is never rude to anyone.
questions.description: Though is used to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: …………………………. we burned the midnight oil, we could not meet the deadline.
questions.description: Despite and however are not conjunctions. They cannot connect clauses.

questions.question: She is ill, ……………………….. she is cheerful.
questions.description: Yet is a conjunction. It can connect clauses. However cannot connect two clauses.

questions.question: I must obey ………………………… I have no other option.
questions.description: For can mean because in a very formal or literary style.

questions.question: The doorbell rang …………………………. I sat down to rest.
She is industrious ………………………… her brother is lazy.
I moved to a big city …………………………. I might find a better job.
questions.description: So that indicates purpose.

questions.question: It was ………………………… a brilliant performance that the applause lasted at least 10 minutes.
questions.description: Use such before a noun with an adjective use so before an adjective.

questions.question: ……………………………… I didn’t have enough money, I could not buy the tickets.
questions.description: As gives the reason.

questions.question: ………………………….. I was driving down the road, I saw Rahul walking his dog.
questions.description: As can indicate time. It can introduce a longer background action that was going on when another action took place.

questions.question: They will have to abandon the project ……………………………. you do not support them.
questions.description: If indicates a condition.

questions.question: I will be ready ................... the time you return.
questions.description: By means not later than.

questions.question: You must finish the job ...................... you leave.
I screamed ..................... I saw the snake.
questions.description: The moment means as soon as.

questions.question: I hurt myself .................... I was hiking yesterday.
questions.description: While and when are used to talk about something that happened on one occasion.

questions.question: I hurt myself ..................... I go hiking.
I will be ready when you ....................
questions.description: When both clauses refer to the future, we use a simple present tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: I stayed an extra day .............................. I could see more places.
questions.description: So that indicates purpose.

questions.question: ...................... in doubt, read the instruction manual.
Cook on low flames ....................... the soup is ready.
..................... you know, I was never interested in this.
The man ...................... she married was an old friend of mine.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses both that and whom can be used to refer to people.

questions.question: She always thanks me for the all favors ....................... I do her.
questions.description: A that -clause is more common after words like all or any.

questions.question: I was ill .......................... I didn't go to work.
questions.description: The conjunction 'so' shows the result whereas the conjunctions as and because show the cause.

questions.question: You should get your license renewed at once ................... pay a fine.
questions.description: The conjunction 'or' is used to present alternatives.

questions.question: .......................... there is no demand for this type of book, I cannot place an order.
questions.description: The conjunctions as and since are used to give the reason.

questions.question: My grandfather has never flown in an airplane .......................... does he want to fly in one.
questions.description: Neither and nor can mean 'also not'. They can come at the beginning of a clause and are followed by an inverted word order.

questions.question: I am very tired ................................ I have been working all day.
She not only gave us a fine dinner ......................... drove us back home.
questions.description: The correct expression is not only / but also.

questions.question: Cold ............................. it was, we went out.
questions.description: After an adjective or adverb, as and though can be used to mean 'although'. Note that although is not possible in this structure.

questions.question: I am not angry. ............................. anything I feel a little surprised.
questions.description: If can be used before non-assertive words like any, anything, ever and not.

questions.question: The Kaziranga National Park is a World Heritage Site ....................... hosts two-thirds of the one-horned rhinoceros in the world.
questions.description: 'That' is a relative pronoun but it is also possible here.

questions.question: August 31st is a national holiday ............................ everybody dances in the streets.
questions.description: When indicates time where indicates place. That cannot be used instead of when or where.

questions.question: Strange ............................ it may sound, I don't like watching cricket.
questions.description: After an adjective or an adverb, as and though can be used in a special structure.

questions.question: Coming late, James tiptoed into the room —————— he should disturb the class.
I worked hard —————– I might win the first prize.
She spoke in such a low voice —————- few could hear her.
She was —————– weak that she could hardly stand.
That is Peter, —————– I am mistaken.
We will have plenty to eat ——————- that no uninvited guests turn up.
I will forgive you ——————– you don’t repeat the offence.
They were disappointed ——————- you weren’t in.
There will be no trouble —————- you keep your mouth shut.
——————– were his words and gestures that the listeners were hypnotized.
